column1: #Text=is a town of 2,000 people ( 2016 ) in Central Newfoundland .
#Text=That name dated back to the 18th century and supposedly it referred to a massacre of a family of 11 by Beothuk Aboriginals that were living in the area at the time .
#Text=The town was renamed Alexander Bay in 1894 .
#Text=During 1894 , a section of railway was being built in the area .
#Text=A few years later the town was renamed " Glovertown " , after Sir John Hawley Glover who served as the Governor of Newfoundland from 1876 to 1881 and from 1883 to 1885 .
#Text=The first settlers of Glovertown appeared in the early 19th century .
#Text=By 1857 there were only 10 and by 1862 there Glovertown became a thriving center for the fishery , boat building and lumbering industries .
#Text=In 1913 , one of the sawmills at Rosedale exploded and six people were killed .
#Text=In 1946 there was a fire that was started by sparks coming from a passing train .
#Text=Two schools , several businesses and 390 km ² of timber were also destroyed during the fire .
#Text=The lumber industry has never recovered from this loss .

#Text=Eventually people from Greenspond , Flat Island , Bragg 's Island , and Gooseberry Island began to resettle to Glovertown and the influx of new people brought new industries to the town , including dairy and construction .
#Text=Glovertown can be accessed via Trans-Canada Highway 1 east of Gander and Gambo and west of Terra Nova National Park .
#Text=There are two exits : one that leads directly onto Station Road in Glovertown and another that leads to Eastport and Traytown .
#Text=Glovertown is primarily a one street town , with other smaller residential roads along the way .
#Text=You can arrive through Traytown on Main Street North or through Station Road and from there , you just have to follow Main Street .
#Text=The museum was developed with the theme of resettlement in mind , which is the story of people 's movement from the Islands of Bonavista Bay to ' growth centres ' such as Glovertown .
#Text=Other themes at the museum include boat building , the Spring log drive , and general Glovertown history and heritage .
#Text=( on the Trans-Canada Highway five minutes east from the Station Road exit ) , ☏ +1709 533-2753 , toll-free : +1-844-533-2753 .
#Text=A family water park that offers a range of activities and services .
#Text=Splash n ’ Putt offers a gift shop , restaurant , dairy bar and cabins ( $ 136 - 194 double ) .
#Text=Heated outdoor pool , decks on most units , laundry facilities on site , boat launch , fire pit , barbecue is most suites , WiFi and cable TV .
#Text=, 13 Pinetree Road , ☏ +1709 533-6038 . $ 115 - 133 includes a home cooked breakfast for two .
#Text=The landscape of the park varies from the rugged cliffs and sheltered inlets of the coastal region to the rolling forested hills , bogs and ponds of the inland .
#Text=Popular summer activities in the Park include camping , hiking , canoeing , kayaking , biking and boat tours .
#Text=Winter is also a good time to explore the park by cross-country skiing or snowshoeing the trails and winter camping at Newman Sound .
